column3: Prince Rwagasore was assassinated]], robbing Burundi of its most popular and well-known nationalists.<ref name=""state""/><ref>[http://web.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v7/v7i1a5.htm ""Ethnicity and Burundi’s Refugees""] {{webarchive
column5: date=5 January 2009 }}, ''African Studies Quarterly: The online journal for African Studies''. Retrieved 12 July 2008.</ref>

column1: The country claimed independence on 1 July 1962,<ref name=""state""/> and legally changed its name from Ruanda-Urundi to Burundi.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title = What Happened Where: A Guide to Places and Events in Twentieth-Century
column10: page= 281}}</ref> Burundi became a [[constitutional monarchy]] with Mwami Mwambutsa IV, Prince Rwagasore's father, serving as the country's king.<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk""/> On 18 September 1962 Burundi joined the [[United Nations]].<ref>[https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2006/org1469.doc.htm United Nations Member States] {{Webarchive

column1: In 1963, King Mwambutsa appointed a Hutu prime minister, [[Pierre Ngendandumwe]], but he was assassinated on 15 January 1965 by a Rwandan Tutsi employed by the US Embassy. The assassination occurred in the broader context of the [[Congo Crisis]] during which [[Western world
column2: Western]] anti-communist countries were confronting the communist [[People's Republic of China]] as it attempted to make Burundi a logistics base for communist insurgents battling in Congo.<ref>[[#Lemarchand1996
column4: Parliamentary elections in May 1965]] brought a majority of Hutu into the parliament, but when King Mwambutsa appointed a Tutsi prime minister, some Hutu felt this was unjust and ethnic tensions were further increased. In October 1965, an attempted [[1965 Burundian coup d'état
column5: coup d'état]] led by the Hutu-dominated police was carried out but failed. The Tutsi dominated army, then led by Tutsi officer Captain [[Michel Micombero]]<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk"">{{cite news
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> purged Hutu from their ranks and carried out reprisal attacks which ultimately claimed the lives of up to 5,000 people in a precursor to the [[Ikiza
column16: date=15 November 2017 }}. University of Massachusetts Amherst</ref>

column1: King Mwambutsa, who had fled the country during the October coup of 1965, was deposed by a [[July 1966 Burundian coup d'état
column2: coup in July 1966]] and his teenage son, [[Ntare V of Burundi
column3: Prince Ntare V]], claimed the throne. In November that same year, the Tutsi Prime Minister, then-Captain Michel Micombero, carried out another [[November 1966 Burundian coup d'état
column4: coup]], this time deposing Ntare, abolishing the monarchy and declaring the nation a [[republic]], though his one-party government was effectively a [[military dictatorship]].<ref name=""state""/> As president, Micombero became an advocate of [[African socialism]] and received support from the People's Republic of China. He imposed a staunch regime of law and order and sharply repressed Hutu militarism.

column1: In late April 1972, two events led to the outbreak of the [[Burundian genocide (1972)
column2: First Burundian Genocide]]. On 27 April 1972, a rebellion led by [[Hutu]] members of the [[gendarmerie]] broke out in the lakeside towns of [[Rumonge]] and [[Nyanza-Lac]] and the rebels declared the short-lived [[Martyazo Republic]].<ref>[[#Lemarchand1996
column3: Lemarchand (1996)]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=T8W6RfqiYf0C&pg=PA89 p. 89]</ref><ref>Lemarchand, (2008). Section ""B – Decision-Makers, Organizers and Actors""</ref> The rebels attacked both Tutsi and any Hutu who refused to join their rebellion.<ref name=""totten1"">{{cite book

column2: title=Century of Genocide: Critical Essays and Eyewitness Accounts

column1: Manirakiza, Marc (1992) ''Burundi : de la révolution au régionalisme, 1966–1976'', Le Mât de Misaine, Bruxelles, pp. 211–212.
</ref> During this initial Hutu outbreak, anywhere from 800 to 1200 people were killed.<ref>

Lemarchand, (2008). Section ""B – Decision-Makers, Organizers and Actors"" cites (Chrétien Jean-Pierre and Dupaquier, Jean-Francois, 2007, ''Burundi 1972: Au bord des génocides'', Paris: L'Harmattan. p. 106)

</ref> At the same time, King [[Ntare V of Burundi]] returned from exile, heightening political tension in the country. On 29 April 1972, the 24-year-old Ntare V was murdered. In subsequent months, the Tutsi-dominated government of [[Michel Micombero]] used the army to combat Hutu rebels and commit genocide, murdering targeted members of the Hutu majority. The total number of casualties was never established, but contemporary estimates put the number of people killed between 80,000 and 210,000.<ref name=""white"">White, Matthew. [http://users.erols.com/mwhite28/warstat2.htm#Rwanda Death Tolls for the Major Wars and Atrocities of the Twentieth Century: C. Burundi (1972–73, primarily Hutu killed by Tutsi) 120,000] {{Webarchive

International Commission of Inquiry for Burundi (2002). Paragraph 85. ""The Micombero regime responded with a genocidal repression that is estimated to have caused over a hundred thousand victims and forced several hundred thousand Hutus into exile""
</ref> In addition, several hundred thousand Hutu were estimated to have fled the killings into [[Zaïre]], [[Rwanda]] and [[Tanzania]].<ref name=""ICIBFR-85"" /><ref>{{cite book

column2: title=Proxy Targets: Civilians in the War in Burundi

column1: Following the civil war and genocide, Micombero became mentally distraught and withdrawn. In 1976, Colonel [[Jean-Baptiste Bagaza]], a Tutsi, led a [[1976 Burundian coup d'état
column2: bloodless coup]] to topple Micombero and set about promoting reform. His administration drafted a new constitution in 1981, which maintained Burundi's status as a [[one-party state]].<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk""/> In August 1984, Bagaza was elected head of state. During his tenure, Bagaza suppressed political opponents and religious freedoms.

column1: Major [[Pierre Buyoya]], a Tutsi, [[1987 Burundian coup d'état
column2: overthrew Bagaza in 1987]], suspended the constitution and dissolved political parties. He reinstated military rule by a Military Committee for National Salvation (CSMN).<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk""/> Anti-Tutsi ethnic propaganda disseminated by the remnants of the 1972 UBU, which had re-organized as PALIPEHUTU in 1981, led to killings of Tutsi peasants in the northern communes of [[Ntega]] and [[Marangara]] in August 1988. The government put the death toll at 5,000{{citation needed
column3: date=July 2013}}; some international NGOs believed this understated the deaths.

column1: The new regime did not unleash the harsh reprisals of 1972. Its effort to gain public trust was eroded when it decreed an [[amnesty]] for those who had called for, carried out, and taken credit for the killings. Analysts have called this period the beginning of the ""culture of impunity."" Other analysts put the origins of the ""culture of impunity"" earlier, in 1965 and 1972, when a small number of identifiable Hutus unleashed massive killings of Tutsis.{{citation needed

In the aftermath of the killings, a group of Hutu intellectuals wrote an open letter to [[Pierre Buyoya]], asking for more representation of the Hutu in the administration. They were arrested and jailed. A few weeks later, Buyoya appointed a new government, with an equal number of Hutu and Tutsi ministers. He appointed [[Adrien Sibomana]] (Hutu) as Prime Minister. Buyoya also created a commission to address issues of national unity.<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk""/> In 1992, the government created a new constitution that provided for a multi-party system,<ref name=""news.bbc.co.uk""/> but a [[civil war]] broke out.
An estimated total of 250,000 people died in Burundi from the various conflicts between 1962 and 1993.<ref>
Hagget, Peter. ''Encyclopedia of World Geography''. Tarrytown, New York: Marshall Cavendish, 2002. {{ISBN
Since Burundi's independence in 1962, two [[Burundi genocide (disambiguation)
column2: genocides]] have taken place in the country: the 1972 mass killings of Hutus by the Tutsi-dominated army,<ref>[http://www.preventgenocide.org/edu/pastgenocides/burundi/resources/ Past genocides, Burundi resources] {{Webarchive
column4: date=25 March 2017}} on the website of [[Prevent Genocide International]]

column1: * Michael Bowen, ''Passing By;: The United States and Genocide in Burundi'', 1972, (Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, 1973), 49 pp.
* René Lemarchand, ''Selective genocide in Burundi'' (Report – Minority Rights Group; no. 20, 1974), 36 pp.
* Edward L. Nyankanzi, ''Genocide: Rwanda and Burundi'' (Schenkman Books, 1998), 198 pp.
* Christian P. Scherrer, ''Genocide and crisis in Central Africa : conflict roots, mass violence, and regional war''; foreword by [[Robert Melson (political scientist)

column2: title=Preventing Genocide in Burundi Lessons from International Diplomacy

column1: [[United States Institute of Peace]]</ref> and the mass killings of Tutsis in 1993 by the Hutu majority. Both were described as genocides in the final report of the International Commission of Inquiry for Burundi presented in 2002 to the [[United Nations Security Council]].<ref name=ICIBFR-85-496>
International Commission of Inquiry for Burundi (2002). Paragraphs 85,496.
===First attempt at democracy and war between Tutsi National Army and Hutu population===

In June 1993, [[Melchior Ndadaye]], leader of the Hutu-dominated [[Front for Democracy in Burundi]] (FRODEBU), won the first democratic election. He became the first Hutu head of state, leading a pro-Hutu government. Though he attempted to smooth the country's bitter ethnic divide, his reforms antagonised soldiers in the Tutsi-dominated army, and he was assassinated amidst a failed military coup in October 1993, after only three months in office. The ensuing [[Burundian Civil War]] (1993–2005) saw persistent violence between Hutu rebels and the Tutsi majority army. It is estimated that some 300,000 people, mostly civilians, were killed in the years following the assassination.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/country_profiles/1068873.stm Country profile Burundi] BBC. {{Webarchive

In early 1994, the parliament elected [[Cyprien Ntaryamira]] (Hutu) to the office of president. He and [[Juvénal Habyarimana]], the president of Rwanda, both Hutus, died together [[Assassination of Habyarimana and Ntaryamira
column2: when their airplane was shot down]] in April 1994. More refugees started fleeing to Rwanda. Speaker of Parliament, [[Sylvestre Ntibantunganya]] (Hutu), was appointed as president in October 1994. A coalition government involving 12 of the 13 parties was formed. A feared general massacre was averted, but violence broke out. A number of Hutu refugees in Bujumbura,{{citation needed
column3: date=July 2013}} the then-capital, were killed. The mainly Tutsi Union for National Progress withdrew from the government and parliament.

column1: In 1996, [[Pierre Buyoya]] (Tutsi) again took power through a [[1996 Burundian coup d'état
column2: coup d'état]]. He suspended the constitution and was sworn in as president in 1998. This was the start of his second term as president, after his first term from 1987 to 1993. In response to rebel attacks, the government forced much of the population to move to [[refugee camp]]s.{{cn
column3: date=February 2023}} Under Buyoya's rule, long peace talks started, mediated by [[South Africa]]. Both parties signed agreements in [[Arusha]], [[Tanzania]] and [[Pretoria]], South Africa, to share power in Burundi. The agreements took four years to plan.
alt=color map of African countries showing Uganda Rwanda and Burundi backing rebels against Kabila
column4: Belligerents of the [[Second Congo War]]. Burundi backed the rebels.]]

column1: On 28 August 2000, a transitional government for Burundi was planned as a part of the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement. The transitional government was placed on a trial basis for five years. After several aborted cease-fires, a 2001 peace plan and power-sharing agreement has been relatively successful. A cease-fire was signed in 2003 between the Tutsi-controlled Burundian government and the largest Hutu rebel group, CNDD-FDD (National Council for the Defense of Democracy-Forces for the Defense of Democracy).<ref>[http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/OCHA-64D9N7?OpenDocument Global Ceasefire Agreement between Burundi and the CNDD-FDD]. 20 November 2003. ''Relief Web''. United Nations Security Council. Retrieved 24 July 2008.</ref>
In 2003, FRODEBU leader [[Domitien Ndayizeye]] (Hutu) was elected president.{{cn
column2: date=February 2023}} In early 2005, ethnic quotas were formed for determining positions in Burundi's government. Throughout the year, elections for parliament and president occurred.<ref>{{cite web

column1: [[Pierre Nkurunziza]] (Hutu), once a leader of a rebel group, was elected president in 2005. {{As of
column2: 2008}}, the Burundian government was talking with the Hutu-led Palipehutu-National Liberation Forces (NLF)<ref>Haskin, Jeanne M. (2005) ''The Tragic State of the Congo: From Decolonization to Dictatorship''. New York, NY: Algora Publishing, {{ISBN
column3: 0-87586-416-3}} p. 151.</ref> to bring peace to the country.<ref>Liang, Yin (4 June 2008). [http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-06/04/content_8308846.htm ""EU welcomes positive developments in Burundi""] {{Webarchive
column5: date=25 January 2017 }}. ''China View''. Xinhua News Agency. Retrieved on 29 June 2008.</ref>

column1: African leaders began a series of peace talks between the warring factions following a request by the United Nations Secretary General [[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]] for them to intervene in the humanitarian crisis. Talks were initiated under the aegis of former Tanzanian President [[Julius Nyerere]] in 1995; following his death, South African President [[Nelson Mandela]] took the helm. As the talks progressed, South African President [[Thabo Mbeki]] and United States President [[Bill Clinton]] also lent their respective weight.

The peace talks took the form of [[Track I mediation]]s. This method of negotiation can be defined as a form of diplomacy involving governmental or intergovernmental representatives, who may use their positive reputations, mediation, or the ""carrot and stick"" method as a means of obtaining or forcing an outcome, frequently along the lines of ""bargaining"" or ""win-lose"".<ref>{{cite book

The main objective was to transform the Burundian government and military structurally in order to bridge the ethnic gap between the Tutsi and Hutu. It was to take place in two major steps. First, a transitional power-sharing government would be established, with the presidents holding office for three-year terms. The second objective involved a restructuring of the armed forces, where the two groups would be represented equally.

As the protracted nature of the peace talks demonstrated, the mediators and negotiating parties confronted several obstacles. First, the Burundian officials perceived the goals as ""unrealistic"" and viewed the treaty as ambiguous, contradictory and confusing. Second, and perhaps most importantly, the Burundians believed the treaty would be irrelevant without an accompanying cease fire. This would require separate and direct talks with the rebel groups. The main Hutu party was skeptical of the offer of a power-sharing government; they alleged that they had been deceived by the Tutsi in past agreements.

column3: title=Jan van Eck – peace mediator in Burundi
column7: access-date=4 July 2019}}</ref> the Burundian President signed the treaty, as well as 13 of the 19 warring Hutu and Tutsi factions. Disagreements persisted over which group would preside over the nascent government, and when the ceasefire would begin. The spoilers of the peace talks were the hardliner Tutsi and Hutu groups who refused to sign the accord; as a result, violence intensified. Three years later at a summit of African leaders in Tanzania, the Burundian president and the main opposition Hutu group signed an accord to end the conflict; the signatory members were granted ministerial posts within the government. However, smaller militant Hutu groups – such as the Forces for National Liberation – remained active.

column1: Between 1993 and 2003, many rounds of peace talks, overseen by regional leaders in Tanzania, South Africa and [[Uganda]], gradually established power-sharing agreements to satisfy the majority of the contending groups. Initially the South African Protection Support Detachment was deployed to protect Burundian leaders returning from exile. These forces became part of the [[African Union Mission in Burundi
column2: African Union Mission to Burundi]], deployed to help oversee the installation of a transitional government. In June 2004, the UN stepped in and took over peacekeeping responsibilities as a signal of growing international support for the already markedly advanced peace process in Burundi.<ref name=""Howard, Lise Morje 2008"">Howard, Lise Morje (2008). UN Peacekeeping in Civil Wars. New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref>

column1: The mission's mandate, under [[Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter]], has been to monitor cease-fire, carry out disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration of former military personnel, support humanitarian assistance and refugee and IDP return, assist with elections, protect international staff and Burundian civilians, monitor Burundi's troublesome borders, including halting illicit arms flows, and assist in carrying out institutional reforms including those of the Constitution, judiciary, armed forces and police. The mission has been allotted 5,650 military personnel, 120 civilian police and about 1,000 international and local civilian personnel. The mission has been functioning well. It has greatly benefited from the transitional government, which has functioned and is in the process of transitioning to one that will be popularly elected.<ref name=""Howard, Lise Morje 2008""/>

The main difficulty in the early stages was continued resistance to the peace process by the last Hutu nationalist rebel group. This organisation continued its violent conflict on the outskirts of the capital despite the UN's presence. By June 2005, the group had stopped fighting and its representatives were brought back into the political process. All political parties have accepted a formula for inter-ethnic power-sharing: no political party can gain access to government offices unless it is ethnically integrated.<ref name=""Howard, Lise Morje 2008""/>

The focus of the UN's mission had been to enshrine the power-sharing arrangements in a popularly voted constitution, so that elections may be held and a new government installed. Disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration were done in tandem with elections preparations. In February 2005, the [[Constitution of Burundi
column2: constitution]] was approved with over 90% of the popular vote. In May, June and August 2005, three separate elections were also held at the local level for the Parliament and the presidency.

column1: While there are still some difficulties with refugee returns and securing adequate food supplies for the war-weary population, the mission managed to win the trust and confidence of a majority of the formerly warring leaders, as well as the population at large.<ref name=""Howard, Lise Morje 2008""/> It was involved with several ""quick effect"" projects, including rehabilitating and building schools, orphanages, health clinics and rebuilding infrastructure such as water lines.

column3: alt=aerial view of highrise building and low rise red roofed buildings
column4: View of the capital city Bujumbura in 2006.]]

column1: Reconstruction efforts in Burundi started to practically take effect after 2006. The UN shut down its peacekeeping mission and re-focused on helping with reconstruction.<ref name=""accessed on 29-10-08"">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/country_profiles/1068991.stm Timeline Burundi] BBC. {{Webarchive
column3: date=30 August 2011 }}. (accessed on 29 October 2008)</ref> Toward achieving [[economic reconstruction]], Rwanda, [[Democratic Republic of the Congo
column4: D.R.Congo]] and Burundi relaunched the regional [[Economic Community of the Great Lakes Countries]].<ref name=""accessed on 29-10-08""/> In addition, Burundi, along with Rwanda, joined the [[East African Community]] in 2007.

column1: However, the terms of the September 2006 Ceasefire between the government and the last remaining armed opposition group, the [[National Liberation Front (Burundi)
column2: FLN]] (Forces for National Liberation, also called NLF or FROLINA), were not totally implemented, and senior FLN members subsequently left the truce monitoring team, claiming that their security was threatened.<ref>{{cite web
column8: archive-date=13 May 2009}}. Amnesty International</ref> In September 2007, rival FLN factions clashed in the capital, killing 20 fighters and causing residents to begin fleeing. Rebel raids were reported in other parts of the country.<ref name=""accessed on 29-10-08""/> The rebel factions disagreed with the government over disarmament and the release of political prisoners.<ref name=""hrw.org"">[https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/05/29/burund18974.htm Burundi: Release Civilians Detained Without Charge
column11: date=2 June 2008 }}. Hrw.org (29 May 2008). Retrieved on 24 November 2012.</ref> In late 2007 and early 2008, FLN combatants attacked government-protected camps where former combatants were living. The homes of rural residents were also pillaged.<ref name=""hrw.org""/>

column1: The 2007 report<ref name=""hrw.org""/> of [[Amnesty International]] mentions many areas where improvement is required. Civilians are victims of repeated acts of violence done by the FLN. The latter also recruits child soldiers. The rate of violence against women is high. Perpetrators regularly escape prosecution and punishment by the state. There is an urgent need for reform of the judicial system. [[Genocide]], [[war crimes]] and [[crimes against humanity]] continued to go unpunished.{{citation needed

In late March 2008, the FLN sought for the parliament to adopt a law guaranteeing them 'provisional immunity' from arrest. This would cover ordinary crimes, but not grave violations of international humanitarian law like war crimes or crimes against humanity .<ref name=""hrw.org""/> Even though the government has granted this in the past to people, the FLN has been unable to obtain the provisional immunity.

On 17 April 2008, the FLN bombarded Bujumbura. The Burundian army fought back and the FLN suffered heavy losses. A new ceasefire was signed on 26 May 2008. In August 2008, President Nkurunziza met with the FLN leader [[Agathon Rwasa]], with the mediation of [[Charles Nqakula]], South Africa's Minister for Safety and Security. This was the first direct meeting since June 2007. Both agreed to meet twice a week to establish a commission to resolve any disputes that might arise during the peace negotiations.<ref>[http://www.pbcupdate.org/?p=114#more-114 Peace Building Commission Update, A project of the Institute for Global Policy] {{Webarchive

The UN has attempted to evaluate the impact of its peace-building initiatives. In the early 2010s, the UN peacekeeping mission in Burundi sought to assess the success of its Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration program by counting the number of arms that had been collected, given the prevalence of arms in the country. However, these evaluations failed to include date from local populations, which are significant in impact evaluations of peacebuilding initiatives.<ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=The Frontlines of Peace: An Insider's Guide to Changing the World

column1: As of 2012, Burundi was participating in African Union peacekeeping missions, including the [[African Union Mission to Somalia
column2: mission to Somalia]] against Al-Shabaab militants.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/11/201211711223399246.html Explosion rocks Somali parliament – Africa] {{Webarchive
column4: date=6 June 2017}}. Al Jazeera English (7 November 2012). Retrieved on 24 November 2012.</ref> In 2014, the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Burundi)
column5: Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] was established, initially for four years and then extended for another four in 2018.<ref name=reuters2014>{{cite web
column8: title=Burundi creates reconciliation body that divides public opinion
column13: title=Burundi: the commission of divided truths

column1: In April 2015 protests broke out after the ruling party announced President [[Pierre Nkurunziza]] would seek a third term in office.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: df = dmy-all}}</ref> Protestors claimed Nkurunziza could not run for a third term in office but the country's constitutional court agreed with Nkurunziza (although some of its members had fled the country at the time of its vote).<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-32588658 ""Burundi court backs President Nkurunziza on third-term""] {{Webarchive

column2: An attempted coup d'état on 13 May]] failed to depose Nkurunziza.

column3: title=Gun clashes rage on in Burundi as radio station attacked
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> He returned to Burundi, began purging his government, and arrested several of the coup leaders.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/15/burundi-president-returns-to-divided-capital-after-failed-coup ""Burundi's president returns to divided capital after failed coup""] {{Webarchive
column11: date=20 October 2017 }}. ''The Guardian'' (15 May 2015). Retrieved on 29 June 2015.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-32724083 ""Burundi general declares coup against President Nkurunziza""] {{Webarchive
column13: date=11 July 2018 }} BBC</ref><ref name=cnn01>[http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/15/africa/burundi-coup-leaders-arrested/index.html Burundi arrests leaders of attempted coup] {{Webarchive
column15: date=16 May 2017 }}. CNN.com (15 May 2015). Retrieved on 29 June 2015.</ref><ref>Laing, Aislinn. (15 May 2015) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/burundi/11607171/Burundi-coup-fails-as-president-returns-to-the-country.html ""Burundi president hunts for coup leaders as he returns to the capital""] {{Webarchive
column17: date=30 January 2018 }}. ''Daily Telegraph''. Retrieved on 29 June 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/05/president-burundi-army-coup-failed-150515002113225.html ""President 'back in Burundi' after army says coup failed""] {{Webarchive
column19: date=5 June 2017 }}. Al Jazeera English (15 May 2015). Retrieved on 29 June 2015.</ref> Following the attempted coup, protests however continued and over 100,000 people had fled the country by 20 May causing a humanitarian emergency. There are reports of continued and widespread abuses of human rights, including unlawful killings, torture, disappearances, and restrictions on freedom of expression.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/countries/africa/burundi/report-burundi/ ""Burundi 2015/6""] {{Webarchive
column21: date=15 January 2018 }}, Amnesty International. Retrieved 10 April 2016.</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/10/burundi-ethnic-violence-refugees ""We feel forgotten""] {{Webarchive

column1: Despite calls by the [[United Nations]], the [[African Union]], the United States, France, [[South Africa]], Belgium, and various other governments to refrain, the ruling party [[Burundian legislative election, 2015
column2: held parliamentary elections on 29 June]], but these were boycotted by the opposition.

column1: On 30 September 2016, the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] established the Commission of Inquiry on Burundi through resolution 33/24. Its mandate is to ""conduct a thorough investigation into human rights violations and abuses committed in Burundi since April 2015, to identify alleged perpetrators and to formulate recommendations.""<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=OHCHR – Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in Burundi
column8: url-status=live}}</ref> On 29 September 2017 the Commission of Inquiry on Burundi called on Burundian government to put an end to serious [[human rights violations]]. It further stressed that, ""The Burundian government has so far refused to cooperate with the Commission of Inquiry, despite the Commission's repeated requests and initiatives.""<ref name=""ohchr.org"">{{cite web
column10: title=OHCHR – Commission calls on Burundian government to put an end to serious human rights violations
column15: url-status=live}}</ref> The violations the Commission documented include [[arrests
column16: arbitrary arrests]] and detentions, acts of [[torture]] and cruel, [[inhuman or degrading treatment]], [[extrajudicial execution]]s, [[enforced disappearances]], [[rape]] and other forms of sexual violence.""<ref name=""ohchr.org""/>

column2: constitutional referendum]] in May 2018, Burundians voted by 79.08% to approve an amended constitution that ensured that Nkurunziza could remain in power until 2034.<ref>{{Cite news
column6: title=In Tiny Burundi, a Huge Vote (Published 2018)
column16: title=Amendments to constitution of Burundi approved: electoral commission – Xinhua {{!}} English.news.cn
column22: website=www.xinhuanet.com}}</ref> However, much to the surprise of most observers, Nkurunziza later announced that he did not intend to serve another term, paving the way for a new president to be elected in the [[2020 Burundian general election
column27: title=President of Burundi, Pierre Nkurunziza, 55, Dies of Heart Attack

column2: Evariste Ndayishimiye]], a candidate who was hand-picked as Nkurunziza's successor by the CNDD-FDD, won the election with 71.45% of the vote.<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=Who is Burundi's new president, Evariste Ndayishimiye?
column7: language=en}}</ref> Shortly after, on 9 June 2020, Nkurunziza died of a cardiac arrest, at the age of 55.<ref name="":03""/> There was some speculation that his death was COVID-19 related, though this is unconfirmed.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=Burundi president dies of illness suspected to be coronavirus
column16: issn=0261-3077}}</ref> As per the constitution, [[Pascal Nyabenda]], the president of the national assembly, led the government until Ndayishimiye's inauguration on 18 June 2020.<ref name="":03"" /><ref name="":1"" />

column2: large prison fire killed dozens]] in the capital city of [[Gitega]].<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Burundi prison fire kills at least 38 in Gitega

column1: In November 2022, in challenges to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] and the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine]], Burundi's economic growth increased slightly to 3 percent, according to an assessment of the [[International Monetary Fund]].
Currently, Burundi remains as one of the poorest nations on Earth after [[Haiti]], based on a [[Gross National Income]] (GNI) of $270 per capita.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Burundi: Fintech Landscape and Potential In The World's Poorest Country

column1: [[File:Pierre Nkurunziza - World Economic Forum on Africa 2008.jpg
column3: alt=Pierre Nkurunziza at World Economic Forum 2008 looking right
column4: [[Pierre Nkurunziza]], President of Burundi from 2005 to 2020.]]

column1: Burundi's political system is that of a [[presidential system
column3: representative democratic]] republic based upon a multi-party state. The president of Burundi is the [[head of state]] and [[head of government]]. There are currently 21 [[List of political parties in Burundi
column4: registered parties in Burundi]].<ref name=""state""/> On 13 March 1992, Tutsi coup leader [[Pierre Buyoya]] established a constitution,<ref name=autogenerated8/> which provided for a multi-party political process and reflected multi-party competition.<ref name=""PH""/> Six years later, on 6 June 1998, the constitution was changed, broadening [[National Assembly of Burundi
column5: National Assembly]]'s seats and making provisions for two vice-presidents. Because of the [[Arusha Accords (Burundi)
column6: Arusha Accord]], Burundi enacted a transitional government in 2000.<ref name=""unburundi""/>

column1: Burundi's legislative branch is a [[bicameral]] assembly, consisting of the Transitional National Assembly and the [[Senate of Burundi
column3: 2004}}, the Transitional National Assembly consisted of 170 members, with the Front for Democracy in Burundi holding 38% of seats, and 10% of the assembly controlled by UPRONA. Fifty-two seats were controlled by other parties. Burundi's constitution mandates representation in the Transitional National Assembly to be consistent with 60% Hutu, 40% Tutsi, and 30% female members, as well as three Batwa members.<ref name=""state""/> Members of the National Assembly are elected by popular vote and serve five-year terms.<ref name=Puddington/>

column1: The Transitional Senate has fifty-one members, and three seats are reserved for former presidents. Due to stipulations in Burundi's constitution, 30% of Senate members must be female. Members of the Senate are elected by electoral colleges, which consist of members from each of Burundi's provinces and communes.<ref name=""state"">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2821.htm Background Note: Burundi]. [[United States Department of State]]. February 2008. Retrieved on 28 June 2008.</ref> For each of Burundi's eighteen provinces, one Hutu and one Tutsi senator are chosen. One term for the Transitional Senate is five years.<ref name=Puddington>{{cite book
column4: title = Freedom in the World: The Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties

column1: Together, Burundi's legislative branch elect the president to a five-year term.<ref name=Puddington/> Burundi's president appoints officials to his Council of Ministers, which is also part of the executive branch.<ref name=""unburundi""/> The president can also pick fourteen members of the Transitional Senate to serve on the Council of Ministers.<ref name=""state""/> Members of the Council of Ministers must be approved by two-thirds of Burundi's legislature. The president also chooses two vice-presidents.<ref name=Puddington/> Following the 2015 election, the president of Burundi was [[Pierre Nkurunziza]]. The first vice-president was Therence Sinunguruza, and the Second Vice-president was Gervais Rufyikiri.<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/world-leaders-1/world-leaders-b/burundi.html Burundi – World Leaders] {{webarchive
On 20 May 2020, [[Evariste Ndayishimiye]], a candidate who was hand-picked as Nkurunziza's successor by the CNDD-FDD, won [[2020 Burundian general election
column2: the election]] with 71.45% of the vote. Shortly after, on 9 June 2020, Nkurunziza died of a cardiac arrest, at the age of 55. As per the constitution, Pascal Nyabenda, the president of the national assembly, led the government until Ndayishimiye's inauguration on 18 June 2020.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=President of Burundi, Pierre Nkurunziza, 55, Dies of Heart Attack
column10: title=Who is Burundi's new president, Evariste Ndayishimiye?

column1: The ''Cour Suprême'' (Supreme Court) is Burundi's highest court. There are three Courts of Appeals directly below the Supreme Court. Tribunals of First Instance are used as judicial courts in each of Burundi's provinces as well as 123 local tribunals.<ref name=""unburundi""/>
Burundi's government has been repeatedly criticised by human rights organisations including [[Human Rights Watch]]<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Burundi: Free Journalist Detained on Treason Charges
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> for the multiple arrests and trials of journalist [[Jean-Claude Kavumbagu]] for issues related to his reporting. [[Amnesty International]] (AI) named him a [[prisoner of conscience]] and called for his ""immediate and unconditional release.""

column1: In April 2009, the government of Burundi changed the law to criminalise [[homosexuality]]. Persons found guilty of consensual same-sex relations risk three months to two years in prison and/or a fine of 50,000 to 100,000 Burundian francs.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=State Sponsored Homophobia 2016: A world survey of sexual orientation laws: criminalisation, protection and recognition
column4: work=[[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]]
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> Amnesty International has condemned the action, calling it a violation of Burundi's obligations under international and regional human rights law, and against the constitution, which guarantees the right to privacy.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2009/04/burundi-elimina-pena-muerte-prohibe-homosexualidad-20090427/ Burundi abolishes the death penalty but bans homosexuality] {{Webarchive

column1: Burundi officially left the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC) on 27 October 2017, the first country in the world to do so.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite news
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> The move came after the UN accused the country of various crimes and human rights violations, such as extrajudicial killings, torture and sexual violence, in a September 2017 report.<ref name="":0"" /> The ICC announced on 9 November 2017 that human rights violations from the time Burundi was a member would still be prosecuted.<ref>{{Cite news
column14: title=We're Not Done Yet, Hague Court Tells Burundi's Leaders

column1: Burundi is divided into 18 [[Provinces of Burundi
column2: provinces]],<ref name=statoids/><!-- defined by transclusion of section:Provinces of Burundi --> 119 [[Communes of Burundi
column6: title=Empowerment of people living with HIV/AIDS in Gitega Province, Burundi
column10: archive-date=19 December 2008}} International Conference on AIDS 2004. 15 July 2004. NLM Gateway. Retrieved on 22 June 2008.</ref> Provincial governments are structured upon these boundaries.

column1: Burundi's provinces and communes were created on Christmas Day in 1959 by a Belgian colonial decree. They replaced the pre-existing system of chieftains.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite web
column4: title=Burundi : Proposition - 5 provinces au lieu de 18 et 42 communes au lieu de 119
column7: website=Nouvelles du Burundi - Africa Generation News

column1: In 2000, the province encompassing Bujumbura was separated into two provinces, Bujumbura Rural and Bujumbura Mairie.<ref name=""xlix"" /> The newest province, [[Rumonge Province
column2: Rumonge]], was created on 26 March 2015 from portions of Bujumbura Rural and Bururi.<ref name=""rumong"">{{cite web
column7: title=LOI N<sup>o</sup> 1/10 DU 26 MARS 2015 PORTANT CREATION DE LA PROVINCE DU RUMONGE ET DELIMITATION DES PROVINCES DE BUJUMBURA, BURURI ET RUMONGE

column1: In July 2022, the government of Burundi announced a complete overhaul of the country's territorial subdivisions. The proposed change would reduce the amounts of provinces from 18 to 5, and reduce the amount of communes from 119 to 42. The change needs the approval of the parliament of Burundi to take effect.<ref name="":2"" />

column4: alt=tan colour map of Burundi with cities

column3: Hippos at Kibira National Park in northwest Burundi]]

column1: One of the smallest countries in Africa, Burundi is landlocked and has an [[Tropical rainforest climate
column2: equatorial climate]]. Burundi is a part of the [[Albertine Rift]], the western extension of the [[East African Rift]]. The country lies on a rolling [[plateau]] in the centre of Africa. Burundi is bordered by [[Rwanda]] to the north, [[Tanzania]] to the east and southeast, and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] to the west. It lies within the [[Albertine Rift montane forests]], [[Central Zambezian miombo woodlands]], and [[Victoria Basin forest-savanna mosaic]] ecoregions.<ref name=""DinersteinOlson2017"">{{cite journal
column101: title=An Ecoregion-Based Approach to Protecting Half the Terrestrial Realm

column1: The average elevation of the central plateau is {{convert
column7: abbr=on}}, with lower elevations at the borders. The highest peak, [[Mount Heha]] at {{convert
column13: abbr=on}},<ref name=""autogenerated2"">O'Mara, Michael (1999). ''Facts about the World's Nations''. [[Bronx, New York]]: H.W. Wilson, p. 150, {{ISBN
column14: 0-8242-0955-9}}</ref> lies to the southeast of the largest city and economic capital, Bujumbura. The source of the [[Nile River]] is in Bururi province, and is linked from Lake Victoria to its headwaters via the [[Ruvyironza River]].<ref name=""autogenerated9"">Ash, Russell (2006). ''The Top 10 of Everything''. New York City: Sterling Publishing Company. {{ISBN
column16: date=April 2010}} [[Lake Victoria]] is also an important water source, which serves as a fork to the [[Kagera River]].<ref>Klohn, Wulf and Mihailo Andjelic. [http://www.fao.org/ag/AGL/AGLW/webpub/lakevic/LAKEVIC4.htm Lake Victoria: A Case in International Cooperation] {{Webarchive
column18: date=8 December 2008 }}. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref><ref>Budge, E. A. Wallace (1907), ''The Egyptian Sudan: Its History and Monuments''. [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania: J. B. Lippincott & Co. p. 352.</ref> Another major lake is [[Lake Tanganyika]], located in much of Burundi's southwestern corner.<ref name=""autogenerated6"">{{cite book
column21: title=An Encyclopedic Dictionary of Conflict and Conflict Resolution, 1945–1996

column1: There are two [[national park]]s: [[Kibira National Park]] to the northwest (a small region of rainforest, adjacent to [[Nyungwe Forest National Park]] in Rwanda), and [[Ruvubu National Park]] to the northeast (along the [[Rurubu River]], also known as Ruvubu or Ruvuvu). Both were established in 1982 to conserve wildlife populations.<ref name=""autogenerated5"">East, Rob (1999). ''African Antelope Database 1998''. [[Gland, Switzerland]]: [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]], p. 74. {{ISBN

column2: List of companies based in Burundi}}

column3: Historical development of GDP per capita]]

column1: Burundi is a landlocked, resource-poor country with an underdeveloped manufacturing sector. The economy is predominantly agricultural, accounting for 50% of GDP in 2017<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=EEAS – European External Action Service – European Commission
column6: access-date=27 August 2019}}</ref> and employing more than 90% of the population. [[Subsistence agriculture]] accounts for 90% of agriculture.<ref name=""autogenerated1"">[[#Eggers
column7: Eggers]], p. xlvii.</ref> Burundi's primary exports are coffee and tea, which account for 90% of foreign exchange earnings, though exports are a relatively small share of GDP. Other agricultural products include cotton, tea, maize, [[sorghum]], sweet potatoes, bananas, [[manioc]] (tapioca); beef, milk and hides. Even though [[Subsistence agriculture
column8: subsistence farming]] is highly relied upon, many people do not have the resources to sustain themselves. This is due to large population growth and no coherent policies governing land ownership. In 2014, the average farm size was about one acre.

column1: Burundi is the world's poorest country, owing in part to its landlocked geography,<ref name=""cia""/> lack of access to education and the proliferation of [[HIV/AIDS]]. Approximately 80% of Burundi's population lives in poverty.<ref>[http://www.iss.co.za/AF/profiles/burundi/Population.html Burundi Population] {{webarchive
column3: date=23 December 2004 }}. Institute for Security Studies. Retrieved on 30 June 2008.</ref> Famines and food shortages have occurred throughout Burundi, most notably in the 20th century,<ref name=""wein5""/> and according to the [[World Food Programme]], 56.8% of children under age five suffer from chronic [[malnutrition]].<ref>{{cite web
column9: archive-date=12 February 2009}} World Food Programme. Retrieved on 30 June 2008.</ref> Burundi's export earnings – and its ability to pay for imports – rests primarily on weather conditions and international coffee and tea prices.[[File:Tree map export 2009 Burundi.jpeg
column11: alt=color chart of exports by value with percentages
column12: Graphical depiction of Burundi's product exports in 28 colour-coded categories in 2009.]]

column1: The purchasing power of most Burundians has decreased as wage increases have not kept up with inflation. As a result of deepening poverty, Burundi will remain heavily dependent on aid from bilateral and multilateral donors. Foreign aid represents 42% of Burundi's national income, the second highest rate in Sub-Saharan Africa. Burundi joined the East African Community in 2009, which should boost its regional trade ties, and also in 2009 received $700 million in debt relief. Government corruption is hindering the development of a healthy private sector as companies seek to navigate an environment with ever-changing rules.<ref name=""cia""/>
Studies since 2007 have shown Burundians to have extremely poor levels of [[Satisfaction with Life Index
column2: satisfaction with life]]; the [[World Happiness Report
column3: World Happiness Report 2018]] rated them the world's least happy.<ref name=""auto1""/><ref>White, A. (2007). [http://data360.org/pdf/20071219073602.A%20Global%20Projection%20of%20Subjective%20Well-being.pdf A Global Projection of Subjective Well-being: A Challenge to Positive Psychology?] {{Webarchive
alt=two sitting in skiff on beach on lakeshore with mountains in bckround

column1: Some of Burundi's natural resources include [[uranium]], nickel, [[cobalt]], [[copper]] and [[platinum]].<ref>[[#Eggers
column2: Eggers]], p. xlviii.</ref> Besides agriculture, other industries include: assembly of imported components; public works construction; food processing and light consumer goods such as blankets, shoes and soap.

column1: In regards to telecommunications infrastructure, Burundi is ranked second to last in the [[World Economic Forum]]'s Network Readiness Index (NRI) – an indicator for determining the development level of a country's information and communication technologies. Burundi ranked number 147 overall in the 2014 NRI ranking, down from 144 in 2013.<ref>{{cite web

Lack of access to financial services is a serious problem for the majority of the population, particularly in the densely populated rural areas: only 2% of the total population holds bank accounts, and fewer than 0.5% use bank lending services. [[Microfinance]], however, plays a larger role, with 4% of Burundians being members of microfinance institutions – a larger share of the population than that reached by banking and postal services combined. 26 licensed microfinance institutions (MFIs) offer savings, deposits and short- to medium-term credit. Dependence of the sector on donor assistance is limited.<ref>{{cite web

Burundi is part of the [[East African Community]] and a potential member of the planned [[East African Federation]]. Economic growth in Burundi is relatively steady but Burundi is still behind neighbouring countries.<ref>[http://www.worlddiplomacy.org/Countries/Burundi/InfoBuru.html Burundi] {{Webarchive
column3: date=26 December 2016 }}. Worlddiplomacy.org. Retrieved on 29 June 2015.</ref>

column1: Burundi's currency is the [[Burundian franc]] (ISO 4217 code BIF). It is nominally subdivided into 100 [[centime]]s, though coins have never been issued in centimes in independent Burundi; centime coins were circulated only when Burundi used the [[congolese franc
Monetary policy is controlled by the [[central bank]], [[Bank of the Republic of Burundi]].{{Exchange Rate

column4: alt=two bicyclists hold on to back of truck descending a hill
column5: Bicycles are a popular means of transport in Burundi]]

column1: Burundi's transport network is limited and underdeveloped. According to a 2012 ''DHL Global Connectedness Index'', Burundi is the least globalised of 140 surveyed countries.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/business/21568753-world-less-connected-it-was-2007-going-backwards Globalisation: Going backwards] {{Webarchive
column3: date=29 June 2017 }}, ''The Economist'' (22 December 2012). Retrieved on 4 April 2014.</ref> [[Bujumbura International Airport]] is the only airport with a paved runway and as of May 2017 it was serviced by four airlines ([[Brussels Airlines]], [[Ethiopian Airlines]], [[Kenya Airways]] and [[RwandAir]]). [[Kigali International Airport
column4: Kigali]] is the city with the most daily flight connections to Bujumbura. The country has a road network but {{As of
column6: lc=y}} less than 10% of the country's roads were paved and {{As of

column2: lc=y}} private bus companies were the main operators of buses on the international route to Kigali; however, there were no bus connections to the other neighbouring countries (Tanzania and the Democratic Republic of Congo).<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=27 August 2019}}</ref> Bujumbura is connected by a passenger and cargo ferry (the [[MV Mwongozo]]) to [[Kigoma]] in Tanzania.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: archive-date=5 April 2017}}</ref> There is a [[East African Railway Master Plan
column13: long-term plan]] to link the country via rail to Kigali and then onward to Kampala and Kenya.

column1: Burundi was ranked 130th in the [[Global Innovation Index]] in 2023.<ref>{{Cite book

column4: Men in colourful clothing with drums]]

column3: alt=three children looking directly at camera

column1: As of October 2021, Burundi was estimated by the [[United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs#Divisions
column2: United Nations]] to have a population of 12,346,893,{{UN_Population
column3: ref}} compared to only 2,456,000 in 1950.<ref>""[http://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/wpp2000/annex-tables.pdf Table 2. Total population by country, 1950, 2000, 2015, 2025 and 2050 (medium-variant)] {{Webarchive
column5: date=8 April 2017 }}"". (PDF). United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs/Population Division. p. 27.</ref> The [[population growth rate]] is 2.5 percent per year, more than double the average global pace, and a Burundian woman has on average 5.10 children, more than double the international [[fertility rate]].<ref name=""FP-March""/> Burundi had the tenth highest [[total fertility rate]] in the world, just behind Somalia, in 2021.<ref name=""cia""/>

column1: Many Burundians have migrated to other countries as a result of the civil war. In 2006, the United States accepted approximately 10,000 Burundian refugees.<ref>Kaufman, Stephen. [http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2006/October/20061017183816esnamfuak0.9061396.html U.S. Accepting Approximately 10,000 Refugees from Burundi] {{webarchive
column3: date=13 February 2008 }}. 17 October 2006. [[U.S. Department of State]]. Retrieved on 30 June 2008.</ref>

column1: Burundi remains an overwhelmingly rural society, with just 13% of the population living in urban areas in 2013.<ref name=""cia""/> The population density of around 315 people per square kilometre (753 per sq mi) is the second highest in [[Sub-Saharan Africa]].<ref name=""state""/> Roughly 85% of the population are of [[Hutu]] ethnic origin, 15% are [[Tutsi]] and fewer than 1% are indigenous [[Great Lakes Twa
The [[official language]]s of Burundi are [[Kirundi]], [[French language
column3: English]]. English was made an official language in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Burundi: l'anglais officialisé aux côtés du français et du kirundi
column9: access-date=2021-07-14}}</ref> Virtually the entire population speaks Kirundi, and just under 10% speak French.<ref>[https://observatoire.francophonie.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Rapport-La-langue-francaise-dans-le-monde_VF-2022.pdf La langue française dans le monde] (2022)</ref>

column1: Sources estimate the Christian population at 80–90%, with Roman Catholics representing the largest group at 60–65%. [[Protestantism
column3: Anglican]] practitioners constitute the remaining 15–25%. An estimated 5% of the population adheres to traditional indigenous religious beliefs. Muslims constitute 2–5%, the majority of whom are [[Sunni Islam
column4: Sunnis]] and live in urban areas.<ref name=""cia""/><ref name=pew>[http://www.globalreligiousfutures.org/countries/burundi/religious_demography#/?affiliations_religion_id=0&affiliations_year=2010 Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project: Burundi] {{Webarchive
column6: date=4 December 2017 }}. [[Pew Research Center]]. 2010.</ref><ref name=""state2010"">[https://web.archive.org/web/20101123105533/http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148667.htm Burundi] . U.S. Department of State. State.gov (17 November 2010). Retrieved on 24 November 2012.</ref>

column1: Burundi has the worst hunger and malnourishment rates of all 120 countries ranked in the [[Global Hunger Index]].<ref name=FP-March>Jillian Keenan, [https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/03/27/the-blood-cries-out-burundi-land-conflict/ The Blood Cries Out] {{Webarchive
column3: date=12 January 2018 }}. ""In one of Africa's most densely populated countries, brothers are killing brothers over the right to farm mere acres of earth. There's just not enough land to go around in Burundi — and it could push the country into civil war."" ''[[Foreign Policy]] (FP)''</ref> The civil war in 1962 put a stop on the medical advancements in the country.<ref name="":4"">{{Cite journal
column4: title=Indigenous medicine and biomedical health care in fragile settings: insights from Burundi
column19: doi-access=free}}</ref> Burundi, again, went into a violent cycle in 2015, jeopardising the citizens of Burundi's medical care.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite web
column21: title=Panalpina flies UNICEF relief to Burundi; 70 tons of primary medical care goods arrived in Burundi
column26: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Like other countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, Burundi uses indigenous medicine in addition to [[biomedicine]]. In the 1980s, Burundi's health authorities asked the United Nations Development Program for support to develop quality control for and begin new research on pharmaceuticals from medicinal plants.<ref name="":4"" /> At the same time, the Burundi Association of Traditional Practitioners (ATRADIBU) was founded, which teamed up with the governments agency to set up the Centre for Research and Promotion of Traditional Medicine in Burundi (CRPMT).<ref name="":4"" /> The recent influx of international aid has supported the work of biomedical health systems in Burundi. However, international aid workers have traditionally stayed away from indigenous medicine in Burundi.<ref name="":4"" /> As of 2015, roughly 1 out of 10 children in Burundi die before the age of 5 from preventable and treatable illnesses such as pneumonia, diarrhoea, and malaria.<ref name="":5"" /> The current violence in Burundi has limited the country's access to medication and hospital equipment. The life expectancy in Burundi, as of 2015, was 60.1 years.<ref name="":8"">{{Cite web
column29: website=Worldmark Encyclopedia of the Nations}}{{Dead link
column32: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In 2013, Burundi spent 8% of their GDP on healthcare.<ref name="":8"" /> While Burundi's fertility rate is 6.1 children per women, the country's infant mortality rate is 61.9 deaths for every 1,000 live births.<ref name="":8"" /> Common diseases in Burundi include malaria and typhoid fever.<ref name="":8"" />

column1: Burundi's culture is based on local tradition and the influence of neighbouring countries, though cultural prominence has been hindered by [[civil unrest]]. Since farming is the main industry, a typical Burundian meal consists of [[sweet potato]]es, [[maize
column2: corn]], [[rice]] and [[pea]]s. Due to the expense, meat is eaten only a few times per month.

column1: When several Burundians of close acquaintance meet for a gathering they drink ''impeke'', a beer, together from a large container to symbolise unity.<ref>{{cite web
column7: archive-date=16 June 2006}} Cultural Profiles Project. Citizenship and Immigration Canada. Retrieved 30 June 2008.</ref>

column1: Notable Burundians include the footballer [[Mohammed Tchité]] and singer [[Jean-Pierre Nimbona]], popularly known as Kidumu (who is based in [[Nairobi]], Kenya).

Crafts are an important art form in Burundi and are attractive gifts to many tourists. Basket weaving is a popular craft for local artisans,<ref>Levin, Adam (2005). ''The Art of African Shopping''. [[Cape Town]], South Africa: Struik, p. 36. {{ISBN
column2: 978-1-77007-070-7}}</ref> as well as other crafts such as masks, shields, statues and pottery.<ref name=r1>{{cite web
column8: archive-date=1 October 2006}} Cultural Profiles Project. Citizenship and Immigration Canada. Retrieved 30 June 2008.</ref>

column1: Drumming is an important part of the cultural heritage. The world-famous [[Royal Drummers of Burundi]], who have performed for over 40 years, are noted for traditional drumming using the [[karyenda]], amashako, ibishikiso and ikiranya drums.<ref>[http://gazette.gmu.edu/articles/8972/ Center for the Arts Presents the Royal Drummers of Burundi] {{Webarchive
column3: date=3 May 2017 }}. ''The Mason Gazette''. 14 September 2006. [[George Mason University]]. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> Dance often accompanies drumming performance, which is frequently seen in celebrations and family gatherings. The abatimbo, which is performed at official ceremonies and rituals and the fast-paced abanyagasimbo are some famous Burundian dances. Some musical instruments of note are the flute, [[zither]], [[ikembe]], indonongo, [[umuduri]], inanga and the inyagara.<ref name=r1/>

column4: alt=five men playing football one red and black striped jersey and four in yellow jersey

column1: The country's [[oral tradition]] is strong, relaying history and life lessons through storytelling, poetry and song. Imigani, indirimbo, amazina and ivyivugo are literary genres in Burundi.<ref>Vansina, Jan (1985). ''Oral Tradition as History''. [[Madison, Wisconsin]]: University of Wisconsin Press, p. 114. {{ISBN

Basketball and track and field are noted sports. Martial arts are popular, as well. There are five major judo clubs: Club Judo de l'Entente Sportive, in Downtown, and four others throughout the city.<ref>{{cite web
column7: archive-date=16 June 2006}}, Cultural Profiles Project. Citizenship and Immigration Canada. Retrieved 20 July 2008.</ref> [[Association football]] is a popular pastime throughout the country, as are [[mancala]] games.

column1: Most Christian holidays are celebrated, with Christmas being the largest.<ref>{{cite web
column7: archive-date=1 October 2006}} Cultural Profiles Project. Citizenship and Immigration Canada. Retrieved 30 June 2008.</ref> Burundian Independence Day is celebrated annually on 1 July.<ref>Trawicky, Bernard and Gregory, Ruth Wilhelme (2000) ''Anniversaries and Holidays'', Chicago, Illinois: American Library Association. p. 110. {{ISBN
column8: 0-8389-0695-8}}</ref> In 2005, the Burundian government declared [[Eid al-Fitr]], an Islamic holiday, to be a public holiday.<ref name=""Burundi celebrates Muslim holiday"">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4402974.stm Burundi celebrates Muslim holiday] {{Webarchive
column10: date=17 June 2017 }}. [[BBC]]. 3 November 2005. Retrieved on 30 June 2008.</ref>

column3: alt=group of children at school in white shirt and khaki shorts uniforms

column1: In 2012, the adult [[literacy]] rate in Burundi was estimated to be 74.71% for men and women between the ages of 15 and 24, while the youth literacy rate was much higher at 92.58%.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite web
column5: website=idea.usaid.gov}}</ref> Burundi has a comparatively high literacy rate to other countries in the region, which is only about 10% lower than the global average<ref name="":3"" />.Ten percent of Burundian boys are allowed a secondary education.<ref>{{cite web
column11: archive-date=1 October 2006}} Cultural Profiles Project. Citizenship and Immigration Canada. cp-pc.ca</ref>

column1: Burundi has one public university, [[University of Burundi]]. There are museums in the cities, such as the [[Burundi Geological Museum]] in [[Bujumbura]] and the [[Burundi National Museum]] and the [[Burundi Museum of Life]] in [[Gitega]].

In 2010 a new elementary school was opened in the small village of Rwoga that is funded by the pupils of Westwood High School, Quebec, Canada.<ref>[http://www.bridge-to-burundi.org/our-goal.php Bridge To Burundi] {{Webarchive
column3: date=26 December 2016 }}. Retrieved on 4 April 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.facebook.com/pages/Westwood-Bridge-to-Burundi/108664129177944 Westwood Bridge to Burundi] {{Webarchive
column5: date=26 December 2016 }}. Facebook. Retrieved on 4 April 2014.</ref>

column1: As of 2022, Burundi invested the equivalent of 5% of its GDP in education.<ref name="":3"" />

Burundi's ''Strategic Plan for Science, Technology, Research and Innovation'' (2013) covers the following areas: food technology; medical sciences; energy, mining and transportation; water; desertification; environmental biotechnology and indigenous knowledge; materials science; engineering and industry; ICTs; space sciences; mathematical sciences; and social and human sciences.

With regard to material sciences, Burundi's publication intensity doubled from 0.6 to 1.2 articles per million inhabitants between 2012 and 2019, placing it in the top 15 for sub-Saharan Africa for this strategic technology.<ref name=""Kingiri & Onana 2021"">{{cite book
column4: title=Central and East Africa. In UNESCO Science Report: the Race Against Time for Smarter Development.

column1: Medical sciences remain the main focus of research: medical researchers accounted for 4% of the country's scientists in 2018 but 41% of scientific publications between 2011 and 2019.<ref name=""Kingiri & Onana 2021""/>

The focus of the ''Strategic Plan for Science, Technology, Research and Innovation'' (2013) has been on developing an institutional framework and infrastructure, fostering greater regional and international co-operation and placing science in society. In October 2014, the EAC Secretariat designated the National Institute of Public Health a centre of excellence. Data are unavailable on output on nutritional sciences, the institute's area of specialization, but between 2011 and 2019, Burundi scientists produced seven articles on each of HIV and tropical communicable diseases and a further five on tuberculosis, all focus areas for the [[Sustainable Development Goals]].<ref name=""Kingiri & Onana 2021""/>

The ''Strategic Plan'' has also focused on training researchers. Researcher density (in head counts) grew from 40 to 55 researchers per million inhabitants between 2011 and 2018. The amount of funding available to each researcher more than doubled from PPP$14,310 (constant 2005 values) to PPP$22,480, since the domestic research effort has also risen since 2012, from 0.11% to 0.21% of GDP.<ref name=""Kingiri & Onana 2021""/>

Burundi has almost tripled its scientific output since 2011 but the pace has not picked up since the adoption of the [[Sustainable Development Goals]] in 2015. With six scientific publications per million inhabitants, Burundi still has one of the lowest publication rate in Central and East Africa.<ref name=""Kingiri & Onana 2021""/> Some 97.5% of publications involved foreign co-authorship between 2017 and 2019, with Ugandans figuring among the top five partners.<ref name=""Kingiri & Onana 2021""/>
